The mention of pro-Russian groups suggests a potential link to ongoing hybrid warfare, aimed at destabilizing European nations. Deutsche Bahn's rapid recovery indicates some resilience, but the incident highlights the need for continuous defense against distributed denial-of-service attacks.
recommandations: Strengthen DDoS mitigation capabilities (traffic filtering, load balancing).
Improve monitoring of information and booking systems for early detection.
Implement business continuity and disaster recovery plans for critical services.
Collaborate with national and international cybersecurity agencies for threat intelligence sharing.
Implement threat awareness training for operational teams.

Articles.title: How infostealers turn stolen credentials into real identities
Articles.description: Analysis by Specops researchers of over 90,000 infostealer dumps, revealing how stolen credentials are tied to real identities, session data, and user activity across personal and enterprise accounts. Infostealers harvest information far beyond usernames and passwords, including Windows usernames, files in user directories, and active session data. Password reuse is identified as a major risk, allowing personal compromises to escalate into enterprise environments. The report highlights that 44.7% of data breaches involve stolen credentials.
Articles.analyse: The study highlights the increasing sophistication of infostealers and the blurring of lines between personal and professional identities in attacks. The value of stolen data extends far beyond simple credentials, enabling targeted phishing, social engineering, and deeper penetration into enterprise environments. The impact is global, potentially affecting any organization whose employees reuse passwords. The risk is amplified by the easy access to these dumps by Initial Access Brokers.
recommandations: Implement strong password policies, including the use of long and unique passphrases.
Use password managers to prevent reuse across personal and professional accounts.
Educate employees about the risks of infostealers and illicit application sources.
Implement multi-factor authentication (MFA) wherever possible.
Continuously scan Active Directory against compromised credential databases to detect and block exposed passwords.

Articles.title: Intelligence Insights: February 2026
Articles.description: This Red Canary report presents the main trends and threats observed in February 2026. It highlights the malicious use of Remote Monitoring and Management (RMM) tools such as ScreenConnect and NetSupport Manager by adversaries. The report also details the emergence of new malicious activity clusters like ClearFake, which injects JavaScript into compromised websites for drive-by downloads and uses fake CAPTCHA or 'paste and run' lures. PS1Bot, a modular PowerShell-based infostealer, is also featured, with its keylogging, screen capture, and information-stealing capabilities, often distributed via SEO poisoning. The report emphasizes the importance of user training and behavioral analysis for detection.
Articles.threat_actor: Scarlet Goldfinch, ClearFake, PS1Bot, Rhadamanthys, D3F@ck Loader, Mocha Manakin, Mintsloader, WARMCOOKIE, Rhysida, Interlock
mitre_ttps: T1204.004 - User Execution: Malicious Copy and Paste
Articles.analyse: The report highlights a diversification of attack vectors, with continued reliance on social engineering and abuse of legitimate functionalities (RMM, PowerShell). The evolution of lure tactics (fake CAPTCHA, paste and run) for initial execution underscores the need for increased user vigilance. The sophistication of ClearFake's execution chains and PS1Bot's modular capabilities demonstrate constant malware adaptation. The impact is primarily on end-users but can propagate to organizations via workstation compromises. The cross-platform nature and use of cloud services (Cloudflare, GitHub) for C2 infrastructure complicate detection.
recommandations: Train users to identify and avoid fake browser update and fake CAPTCHA lures.
Implement strict remote access management policies and monitor RMM usage.
Deploy EDR solutions capable of detecting unusual PowerShell command executions and malicious copy-paste activities.
Use secure web gateways and content filters to block access to compromised and malicious sites.
Strengthen browser and operating system security through regular updates and hardened configurations.

Articles.title: Intellexa’s Predator spyware infected Angolan journalist’s device, Amnesty reports
Articles.description: Amnesty International reveals that Angolan journalist and press freedom advocate, Teixeira Cândido, was infected with Intellexa's Predator spyware in May 2024 via a malicious link sent through WhatsApp. The spyware, sold to governments for surveillance, gave attackers total access to his iPhone, including messages, calls, emails, location, camera, microphone, and passwords. The incident highlights targeted surveillance of journalists and ethical/legal concerns surrounding commercial spyware use. Cândido's phone ran an outdated iOS 16.2, potentially vulnerable to known exploits.
Articles.analyse: The Predator infection by Intellexa underscores the persistence of targeted state surveillance against journalists and activists. The ease of exploitation via WhatsApp links and the spyware's ability to access all device data pose a severe threat to privacy and freedom of expression. The geographical impact is clear, with cases in Angola and a history of Predator being used worldwide. This incident raises serious questions about the responsibility of surveillance companies and the need for stricter international regulation of these technologies.
recommandations: Regularly update mobile device operating systems.
Avoid clicking on suspicious links, even from known contacts.
Use messaging applications with end-to-end encryption and verify the legitimacy of sources.
Conduct regular security audits of devices to detect compromises.
Advocate for international regulation of spyware to prevent its abuse against human rights.

Articles.title: MIMICRAT: ClickFix Campaign Delivers Custom RAT via Compromised Legitimate Websites
Articles.description: Elastic Security Labs uncovered a sophisticated 'ClickFix' campaign using compromised legitimate websites to deliver a five-stage malware chain, culminating in MIMICRAT. MIMICRAT is a native C Remote Access Trojan (RAT) with malleable C2 profiles, token impersonation, and SOCKS5 tunneling. The campaign leverages trust in services like bincheck[.]io and investonline[.]in to load malicious scripts, then uses a fake Cloudflare lure to trick victims into executing a PowerShell command. Advanced evasion techniques (ETW and AMSI bypass, Lua-scripted shellcode loader) are employed. The C2 operates over HTTPS on port 443, mimicking legitimate web analytics traffic.
Articles.analyse: The MIMICRAT campaign demonstrates high operational sophistication, from compromising legitimate websites to advanced evasion techniques and a custom RAT. The use of multiple stages and dynamic localization of lures maximizes the attack's reach and stealth. The impact is significant, enabling persistent access, lateral movement, and token theft. Mimicking legitimate traffic makes signature-based detection more challenging. The geographical impact is broad, targeting victims in multiple regions.
recommandations: Educate users about security verification lures (e.g., Cloudflare) and copy-paste commands.
Implement advanced behavioral monitoring to detect unusual PowerShell activities and ETW/AMSI bypasses.
Block PowerShell script execution from the clipboard if possible.
Conduct regular security audits of websites to detect malicious JavaScript injections.
Use EDR/XDR solutions to detect in-memory shellcode loading and hidden C2 activities.

Articles.title: Nigerian man gets eight years in prison for hacking tax firms
Articles.description: Matthew Abiodun Akande, 37, was sentenced to eight years in prison for hacking multiple tax preparation firms in Massachusetts and filing over 1,000 fraudulent tax returns, seeking over $8.1 million in refunds and collecting over $1.3 million. He used phishing emails impersonating a company CEO to install the Warzone Remote Access Trojan (RAT) and crypters. Once access was gained, he stole clients' personal information for tax fraud. Refunds were directed to bank accounts controlled by co-conspirators in the United States, who transferred a portion of the funds to Mexico.
Articles.analyse: This incident highlights the effectiveness of social engineering (phishing) attacks combined with malware for large-scale financial fraud. Targeting tax firms is strategic due to the wealth of sensitive personal data they hold. The use of off-the-shelf tools (Warzone RAT, crypters) and the complex cross-border money laundering scheme demonstrate operational sophistication. The impact is financial for victims and the state, and privacy-related for clients whose data was stolen. Extradition and conviction underscore judicial efforts to counter transnational cybercrime.
recommandations: Enhance employee training on detecting phishing emails and the importance of verifying links and attachments.
Implement robust antivirus and EDR solutions, configured to detect and block RATs and suspicious encrypted files.
Use MFA to protect access to systems containing sensitive information.
Establish network segmentation and access controls to limit lateral movement in case of compromise.
Conduct regular security audits and penetration tests to identify vulnerabilities.

Articles.title: Normes, Conformité et Post-quantique : Le droit à l’épreuve des ruptures technologiques (2/3) : La propriété intellectuelle : une stratégie pour la course au post quantique ?
Articles.description: Legal and strategic analysis of intellectual property in post-quantum cryptography. The article explores divergences in patentability regimes across the United States, Europe, and China, emphasizing that protection applies not to abstract mathematical algorithms but to their secure technical implementations. It highlights China's aggressive patent strategy for technological sovereignty and the central role of standardization (NIST) in limiting monopolies on algorithms themselves. The example of Thales's Falcon algorithm is used to illustrate how strategic advantage lies in mastering the technical environment, certifications, and secure integration rather than exclusive ownership of the mathematical formula.
Articles.analyse: This analysis document is crucial for understanding the geopolitical and economic stakes of cybersecurity in the post-quantum era. The race for post-quantum cryptography is not only technological but also legal and strategic, with implications for national digital sovereignty. Strategic dependence on standardized algorithms whose implementations are controlled by certain actors poses risks of global network fragmentation and geopolitical arbitrage. The impact is structural on the defense industry, national security, and international technology regulation. The analysis highlights the need for a balance between protected innovation, universal accessibility of standards, and technological sovereignty.
recommandations: Develop national intellectual property strategies aligned with post-quantum cryptography challenges.
Actively participate in international standardization processes to influence technological choices.
Invest in R&D for secure and certifiable technical implementations of post-quantum algorithms.
Educate decision-makers on the legal and strategic implications of algorithms and their patentability.
Establish a 'sui generis' regulatory framework to reconcile exclusivity, standardization, and global accessibility of security algorithms.

Articles.title: PromptSpy is the first known Android malware to use generative AI at runtime
Articles.description: Discovery of PromptSpy, the first known Android malware to integrate generative AI (Google's Gemini model) into its execution flow. PromptSpy uses AI to adapt its persistence across different devices, for instance, by 'locking' the app in the Recent Apps list via Android's Accessibility Service. It also deploys transparent, invisible rectangles over UI buttons to hinder uninstallation. Distribution was observed via the domain mgardownload[.]com and a webpage impersonating JPMorgan Chase Bank, indicating potential use in actual attacks, although distribution appears limited.
mitre_ttps: T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Articles.analyse: The emergence of PromptSpy marks a significant evolution in mobile malware sophistication, demonstrating how generative AI can make threats more dynamic and difficult to detect. The malware's ability to adapt in real-time and hinder uninstallation presents a major challenge for Android security. The impact is primarily on data privacy and the persistence of infections on mobile devices. While initial distribution is limited, this technique is a precursor to future AI-driven threats. The use of fake banking websites indicates a financial motivation for data theft or scamming.
recommandations: Keep Android devices and apps updated.
Avoid downloading apps from untrusted sources (third-party stores, unverified direct links).
Carefully review permissions requested by apps, especially those related to accessibility services.
Use a reliable mobile security solution.
Educate users about phishing and impersonation risks, even on mobile.

Articles.title: Ransomware Trends by Industry: Insights from the GRIT 2026 Ransomware & Cyber Threat Report
Articles.description: GuidePoint Security's GRIT 2026 report reveals that 2025 was a record year for ransomware attacks. The manufacturing industry was most affected (1,060 victims, 14%), followed by the legal (455 victims, +132% year-over-year) and healthcare sectors. Ransomware operators consistently target sectors where operational disruption creates heavy pressure to pay the ransom and where high-value data (PII, PHI) is held. The Akira group claimed responsibility for the highest number of victims in four out of five top industries, while Qilin disproportionately impacted healthcare. Some Ransomware-as-a-Service groups avoid or discourage attacks against healthcare organizations.
Articles.analyse: The report confirms that ransomware remains a major and growing threat, with strategic targeting of industries most sensitive to disruption. The increase in attacks in the legal sector, which holds a 'treasure trove' of sensitive data, is particularly concerning. The impact is financial (ransoms, recovery costs) and operational, with potential consequences for human life in the healthcare sector. The persistence of this threat underscores the need for organizations to strengthen their defenses, incident response capabilities, and vulnerability management.
recommandations: Implement effective threat intelligence programs and incident response frameworks.
Strengthen security operations for greater visibility and reduced remediation time.
Prioritize vulnerability management and penetration testing.
Deploy multi-layered security solutions, including robust data backup and recovery.
Improve network segmentation and multi-factor authentication for all access.

Articles.title: The Immutable Illusion: Pwning Your Kernel with Cloud Files
Articles.description: Elastic Security Labs presents an advancement in exploiting the Windows 'False File Immutability' (FFI) vulnerability class. This novel method leverages the Cloud Files (cldflt.sys) feature to modify in-use executables, which Windows incorrectly assumes are immutable. Unlike previous exploits that used network redirectors (PPLFault), this approach is more streamlined and self-contained, bypassing file sharing restrictions and kernel code integrity checks without requiring a malicious SMB server. The Redux exploit uses CfDehydratePlaceholder and CfHydratePlaceholder to manipulate file state and inject a payload into in-use DLLs, achieving arbitrary code execution with elevated privileges.
mitre_ttps: T1543.003 - Create or Modify System Process: Windows Service
Articles.analyse: This technical research highlights a fundamental design flaw in Windows' file integrity management, enabling kernel-level privilege escalation. The new exploitation method via Cloud Files is particularly concerning because it is stealthier and less reliant on external infrastructure, making its detection more difficult. The impact is highly critical, as it allows for full system compromise. This represents a significant challenge for Windows system security, especially those utilizing cloud synchronization features.
recommandations: Apply Microsoft patches as soon as they are available for FFI vulnerabilities.
Implement EDR/XDR solutions capable of monitoring kernel integrity and detecting modifications to in-memory executable files.
Strengthen security configurations of cloud synchronization services and system drivers.
Conduct in-depth system analysis to identify signs of kernel-level vulnerability exploitation.
Limit application and user access privileges to reduce the attack surface in case of initial compromise.

Articles.title: Thales veut massifier sa production de drones militaires
Articles.description: Éric Lenseigne, VP of Drone Warfare at Thales, announced the goal of 'massification' in the production of loitering munitions (MTOs), targeting 3,000 annual units by 2027 and potentially 10,000 in subsequent years. Thales is developing the Toutatis drone. This initiative is part of a broader trend in the French defense industry (Dassault, Renault, MBDA) to rapidly increase military drone production, in response to growing armed forces needs and sovereignty challenges. Partnerships between large and small specialized MTO companies are being formed to accelerate this mass production.
Articles.analyse: This industrial strategy has major implications for France's national defense and security. The increase in military drone production, particularly loitering munitions, is a direct response to modern conflict evolutions and increased army needs. This positions France as a key player in drone technology, strengthening its sovereignty and capacity to respond to threats. Competition in this market is intense, and the ability to mass-produce is a strategic advantage. The impact is positive for the French defense industry and power projection capability.
recommandations: Continue to invest heavily in R&D to maintain technological leadership in military drones.
Foster public-private partnerships to accelerate innovation and production.
Establish resilient and secure supply chains for drone manufacturing.
Develop counter-drone measures in parallel with increasing offensive drone production.
Implement ethical and legal frameworks for the use of autonomous drones and MTOs.

Articles.title: Texas sues TP-Link over Chinese hacking risks, user deception
Articles.description: Texas filed a lawsuit against TP-Link Systems, accusing the company of deceptively marketing its routers as secure. The complaint alleges that TP-Link allowed Chinese state-backed hackers to exploit firmware vulnerabilities and access users' devices. Furthermore, TP-Link is accused of misleading buyers by labeling its products 'Made in Vietnam' while sourcing almost all components from China, raising national security concerns due to Chinese laws that can compel companies to cooperate with government intelligence requests. A Chinese botnet (Quad7) was identified as using hacked TP-Link routers for attacks.
Articles.analyse: This lawsuit highlights the growing supply chain and geopolitical risks in the technology sector. The allegations against TP-Link raise fundamental questions about trust in network equipment and the security of user data against potential state interference. The impact is not only commercial for TP-Link but also strategic for US national security, given the use of compromised routers in credential theft botnets. Deception about component origin is a major concern in terms of hidden vulnerabilities and potential espionage.
recommandations: Apply available security updates for TP-Link routers and similar devices.
Conduct thorough audits of technology supply chains to verify component origin and security.
Educate consumers and businesses about the risks of equipment from vendors potentially subject to state interference laws.
Implement robust network security measures, including segmentation and traffic monitoring.
Use trusted sources for critical equipment and diversify suppliers.
